issues.title: Support `multiple=True` CLI options in Click again (for tools etc.)
issues.body:
> @ErikBjare
> Not with multiple=True, since it then always returns an empty list and never None, even if the default is None.
>
>> @dodslaser
>>
>> Yes it can. click.Context provides a [get_parameter_source](
https://click.palletsprojects.com/en/stable/api/#click.Context.get_parameter_source) method that should help with that.

Learned from guy on HN: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=44297622

Using this should add back support for multiple `-t` params for instance, by reading the actual source of the parameter (which should let us correctly read the default of None).
issues.author: ErikBjare

issues.title: bug: nested gptme process using shell tool hangs in foreground but works in background
issues.body:
## Summary
`gptme --non-interactive` consistently hangs when run in foreground mode using the shell tool, but works perfectly when run as a background process. This indicates a terminal/TTY handling issue.

## Environment
- gptme version: v0.27.0+fdbc4e5d.dirty
- OS: Arch Linux rolling
- Python: 3.13 (Poetry virtualenv)

## Reproduction Steps

### Foreground Mode (Hangs)
gptme --non-interactive "hi"
Hangs after: [WARNING] Skipping all confirmation prompts.
Never reaches initialization, requires Ctrl+C or timeout to exit

### Background Mode (Works)  
gptme --non-interactive "hi" &
Completes successfully with proper response
Full initialization, API calls, response generation

## Root Cause Hypothesis
Terminal/TTY detection code that behaves differently when stdin/stdout are attached to a real terminal vs detached in background mode.

## Impact
- Non-interactive mode is completely unusable in foreground
- Affects automation scripts and CI/CD pipelines
- Workaround: run as background process, but this is unintuitive

## Next Steps
1. Investigate terminal detection code in CLI initialization
2. Check for stdin reading that should be skipped in non-interactive mode  
3. Review tool initialization for TTY dependencies
issues.author: ErikBjare

comments.author: ErikBjare
comments.body: This is actually quite a high-value way to work on #554, we should be able to treat gptme subagents like any other shell tool that we can run in shell or tmux.

issues.title: Better subagents
issues.body:
I've noticed Claude Code works with tasks/subagents quite a bit, and I think it would make sense for gptme in many circumstances too (such as when it `cd`s into a directory with a new workspace config file, the agent should start a task in that workspace to make sure it gets the right context.

We already have the subagent tool, but it's not refined and prompted enough to be useful (I think). Might need a better return structure? Some way to return/pause to ask for clarification?

We should review how Claude Code works with subagents ("Tasks") exactly, and adopt something similar.

Basically continuing on https://github.com/gptme/gptme/issues/61 (might be a duplicate)
issues.author: ErikBjare

issues.title: Auto-name conversations
issues.body:
We can already give conversations a name automatically with `/rename auto` but this should be improved:

 - [x] Name conversation automatically with `/rename auto`
 - [ ] Don't include date in conversation name, fetch from file/message timestamps.
    - Filesystem metadata not very reliable for this type of thing, but message timestamps are now stored, so should use them. 
 - [ ] Run automatically on save? (if name not already set)
    - https://github.com/ErikBjare/gptme/pull/449
      - This will probably not work for gptme-server, the webui wouldn't get notice of the rename. 
         - Needs special logic, maybe set an "auto" name when we first create a conversation name? Or detect/redirect renames?
      - A different approach would be to not rename the conversation folder names at all, instead keep them as unique IDs and add a (auto-)settable "name" field in the conversation metadata.

issues.title: Managing mutable files
issues.body:
Right now files are stored by path in the conversation log, this makes the content mutable and incorrectly modifies past messages when changes to the files have been made.

 - [ ] Attached files are mutable and their conversation state not preserved: If a file is referenced, we can only read the most recent version.
     - Could be solved by storing referenced files in log dir, perhaps named f"{name}-{hash or version}.{ext}" (something content/version-addressed)

Related:
 - https://github.com/ErikBjare/gptme/issues/262
 - https://github.com/ErikBjare/gptme/pull/281
issues.author: ErikBjare

issues.title: Add `/compact` command
issues.body:
@Miyou reminded me of Claude Code's `/compact` command which does context summarization (somehow) to compact the context.

I've thought about adding it to gptme by reusing our existing summarization logic (that auto-triggers near the context limit) or by creating a new prompt from the conversation (including relevant files etc, more of a "restart" or "continue in new conversation" than a "compact"), but should look into how Claude Code does it exactly.

Old notes I had:

>  - I think the `/compact` command in Claude Code or whatever might be popular/useful in agent contexts for [[gptme]], especially for long-running tasks (or tasks with failed steps), that carries a lot of context.
>     - Feels like we have something like this in gptme for summarization/reduction, but summarization breaks caching since it's not deterministic as it re-runs on every request. 
>         - Better to support explicit compacting steps (possibly callable by agent itself) with auto-compacting option that runs when context passes a threshold (say 50% of the context window)
>    - In gptme, compacting would fork the branch using a reduced message set

Related: https://github.com/gptme/gptme/issues/61
issues.author: ErikBjare

issues.title: Complete "computer use" support
issues.body:
Since Anthropic just announced their computer use stuff (see https://github.com/ErikBjare/gptme/issues/50#issuecomment-2430373560 and [anthropic.com/news/3-5-models-and-computer-use](https://www.anthropic.com/news/3-5-models-and-computer-use)), we should just finish ours as we already have the screenshots.

We can take screenshots, we just need to enable acting on them by clicking or making input.

To not burn tons of tokens we should probably put it in a loop where it doesn't stack tons view/interact steps, maybe use a looping subagent or some kind of context-efficient tool-use loop until goal is achieved (we might need some stuff like this generally for automation goals). Should study how they do it.

They run it in a Docker container and stream it in a webapp using VNC. We should make it possible to do it this way with gptme, but I think gptme should be able to control the local system first, and a Docker system second.


## Milestones

 - Can it Tweet?
 - Can it play Factorio? (prob joke tweet: https://x.com/aphysicist/status/1848802806729228782)
 - Can it play Doom? (latency if we don't want to suck)

issues.title: Placeholder-aware save tool
issues.body:
The save tool often causes the LLM to do stuff like:

````
```save file.py
New first line

# ... rest of the content is the same ...
```
````

~~Which more or less wipes the file.~~ (not anymore after #522)

I noticed once that Lovable seems to handle placeholders when they are saving files, I guess checking for a regex like `(#|//)\s[...].*[...]` and trying to place it into the file somehow. Might be worth setting up a proper test for this, especially to support the output format LLMs (in particular Claude) tend to use.

We are doing some related placeholder handling in the patch tool:

https://github.com/gptme/gptme/blob/4fb3561b7711a373f10bf9144d1282e5d6f8c01d/gptme/tools/patch.py#L174-L181

issues.title: Backtrack conversation on errors and mistakes
issues.body:
When the agent makes an attempt and fails, we include the content in the conversation. This is often costly for the context, and back-tracking with corrective feedback would help keep the conversation on track instead of including the entire mistake.

Could do it simply by checking for the system messages for failed actions, undoing the conversation to the last good point (probably just one "step" back, for now), adding a user message about the failed attempt (maybe), and run it again. Or by simply removing the failed attempts from the conversation history (or replacing them with short messages), this should be done rarely to not affect token caching too badly. Something similar to https://github.com/gptme/gptme/blob/master/scripts/treeofthoughts.py

Would help address issues like failed patches, failed saves (https://github.com/gptme/gptme/issues/520).

Ideally we'd want to be able to test this on a benchmark or something.

issues.title: bug: MCP tools and their config not working in server
issues.body:
Originally reported by @miyou: MCP tools don't work properly in gptme-webui.

## Current behavior

1. All step-requests fail when tools attempt to initialize
2. Error message: 'Tool 'memory_create_entities' not found'
3. Additionally, when memory MCP tools do initialize, they don't persist anything
4. Interestingly, the sqlite MCP tool works correctly, suggesting the issue might be specific to the memory MCP implementation

## Steps to reproduce

1. Have MCP servers configured in config.toml
2. Verify MCP tools work in CLI
3. Open web UI (gptme-webui)
4. Create new conversation
5. Configure MCP in the conversation config
6. Try to use any MCP tool
7. Error: Tool initialization fails

## Expected behavior

MCP tools should work in web UI just as they do in CLI.

## Technical notes

- Tool initialization fails in the server when processing step requests
- Memory MCP tool has additional issue of not persisting state
- SQLite MCP tool works correctly, which might help narrow down the issue
- Need to investigate the tool initialization flow in server context (the memory persistence issue can wait)
issues.author: ErikBjare

issues.title: Making gptme work while you sleep
issues.body:
What I and many seem to want is a way to truly put LLMs to work, ways to outsource higher volumes of work without explicit instruction/live oversight.

I think this is a fascinating problem, and in many ways how I hope to use gptme, but not really there yet.

Ideas:

 - ask it to try implementing feature/fix/refactor x, then typechecking/testing/linting it, then make a PR *if successful*
    - if unsuccessful, attempt up to n retry strategies, possibly in a branching manner where we try to detect the best branch, since any step could go wrong and put it in an unusable state.
      - started working on this in https://github.com/ErikBjare/gptme/pull/199
    - Similar goals to SWE-Bench stuff: https://github.com/ErikBjare/gptme/pull/142
 - various automation workflows, putting it in a cron job, etc.
 - return to the gptme roots and give it your documents/data/activitywatch to inspect and review, condensing it into a daily report or similar
 - browsing the web for content, giving the user recommendations
 - write docs for how to do all these things, give the docs to gptme so you can ask it to write scripts doing it
    - [x] Minimal docs added to https://gptme.org/docs/automation.html in https://github.com/ErikBjare/gptme/pull/144
 - more subagent examples/evals
 - feedback loops, like `make edit to page -> view web page -> make edit`
    - Used it for generating https://github.com/ErikBjare/gptme/blob/master/site/style.css with much success

What we should focus on:
 - Making gptme work on gptme while I sleep

What we'd need:

 - Tool customization
    - It is likely that performance would improve by limiting each step to a restricted set of tools (would at least save on tokens)
       - [x] Implemented `--tools` option in https://github.com/ErikBjare/gptme/commit/48d559b487682a22d7614948270442c529596375
 - Reliable message passing between gptme runs/agents
    - The current subagent mechanism of asking it to output JSON isn't the most reliable. 
       - [x] Maybe making it a prompt chain would fix it? (done in 0dd6583)

Issues:
 - How to avoid burning lots of non-value generating tokens while I sleep?
    - Make reliable, do intelligent tree-search of branches, limit retries
issues.author: ErikBjare

issues.title: Add RAG for code, personal files, and conversations
issues.body:
Source files could be:
 - your projects folder (with code)
 - your notes (in plaintext)
 - past conversations
 - previously web-retrieved documents

Adding this feature would return gptme to its roots: an agent which has context about you and your projects, to intelligently and effectively assist in your work.

## Needs

 - [ ] Configure where to look for source files
   - probably in config
   - could index the current working directory
      - would be problematic for large files, limit to git repos?
 - [ ] Exclude functionality
   - exclude binary files
   - respect git-ignores
 - [ ] Retrieval method
 - [ ] indexing?

## Prompting

The model should be aware of its RAG abilities in the prompt (possibly listing source folder config), and provided a tool for using it.

## Inspiration

- Aider's code map
- PrivateGPT
- LocalGPT
- https://www.anthropic.com/news/contextual-retrieval
   - https://github.com/anthropics/anthropic-cookbook/blob/main/skills/contextual-embeddings/guide.ipynb
issues.author: ErikBjare

mypy test.py

~~~

Which is obviously not right.
issues.author: ErikBjare

issues.title: Add support for ephemeral messages
issues.body:
"Ephemeral messages" are messages which are intended to be dropped after a while, like after a few messages.

To ensure effective prompt caching, we should make sure we request a cache point before the first ephemeral message (since the conversation should be stable up until that point).

Examples could be:
 - `<thinking>` contents
 - Full file contents on failed patches
 - Screenshot outputs in computer use (since screenshots are taken so often)
 - RAG results
issues.author: ErikBjare

issues.title: XML-style prompting
issues.body:
Markdown has some pretty rough limitations that become especially apparent once you need to nest it.

A large class of bugs and workarounds could be eliminated if we switched to XML-style prompting, but on the other hand I've invested so much work into getting the markdown stuff to work that I'm pretty happy with where it is at.

Relevant issues:
 - #67 (making tool calls explicit XML/JSON messages, instead of ambiguous might-be-an-example codeblocks, would fix this)

issues.title: Make a feature comparison table with alternatives
issues.body:
> [!TIP]
> I would love to hear people's experiences about how they think gptme compares to other tools

It would be great to have a feature comparison table like we have in the [ActivityWatch README](https://github.com/ActivityWatch/activitywatch). Helps prospective users understand the differences between alternatives.

Might mean I have to use the alternatives for a bit so I can give it a fair eval.

## Alternatives

 - ChatGPT Code Interpreter
 - Cursor (has "copilot", "composer", and "agent" modes)
 - Aider
 - Open Interpreter
 - Claude Projects: https://x.com/alexalbert__/status/1865073820882886971
 - Claude Desktop
 - Lovable.dev / Bolt.new / etc.

## Dimensions

 - Intended use
    - General purpose
    - IDEs and dev tools
    - No/low-code using codegen
 - Hosting
    - Local (bring your own provider/API key)
    - SaaS
 - Cost / License
 - Funding
    - VC?

## Comparison

Differences to Aider:
 - gptme is less git-commit focused
 - gptme is more general-purpose?
 - gptme has wider array of tools?

Differences to Cursor:
 - gptme is in-terminal instead of in-vscode-fork
 - gptme is extensible with tools, more general-purpose

Differences to Open Interpreter:
 - Idk?

issues.title: Create `gptme-util` CLI command
issues.body:
The main `gptme` cli takes arbitrary strings as input, making it unsuitable for subcommands, which is something I've wanted for a bunch of ideas for utilities I've had.

Adding a `gptme-util` CLI with subcommands would be a way to work around this.

Example subcommands:

 - `gptme-util token(s) count -m $model` - command for counting tokens
 - `gptme-util context generate` - commands for context generation
 - `gptme-util chat(s) ls` - list conversation logs
 - `gptme-util chat(s) read $name` - read & output conversation log in different formats (with filters etc.)
 - `gptme-util tool(s)` - subcommands for tools

issues.title: Dynamic system prompt
issues.body:
- Current date & training cutoff (model-dependent): https://github.com/ErikBjare/gptme/issues/137
    - This seems easy to do, just looks for a date/cutoff-block in the system prompt and replace it if present on each call.
 - Tool selection
    - Currently, we load default tools or those set by `--tools`, but it only impacts the system prompt on the first run.
    - [x] ~~We could change `--tools` to only be valid for new conversations (lame?)~~
       - Would still need us to figure out which tools the conversation was using when loaded.
    - [ ] We could store the loaded tools for the conversation somewhere, so that we can at least resume with the correct toolset.
    - [ ] We could let the user override `--tools` and have it modify the system prompt.


Vaguely related to (similar issues around mutability of conversations):  https://github.com/ErikBjare/gptme/issues/150
issues.author: ErikBjare

comments.author: kennethreitz
comments.body: Curious to see how this develops.

issues.title: Hooks?
issues.body:
One potential way to deal with linting etc is to add a system with hooks that tools can register with.

These hooks could do things like:

 - Generating dynamic system prompt on every message: #151
 - Implement memory (as done by https://pypi.org/project/simplemind/)
 - Interrupt generation on detected tooluse (as currently hard-coded in our llm code)
 - Before running tools: Given an assistant message, react to or transform the message. #152
    - Would work for patch/save-optimization
 - After saving/patching a file: lint/formatting.
    - Maybe shouldn't be a hook?
 - Call out to expert sub-agents to help with problems?
 
...what else?

Not sure if making a "hook" concept like this is the way to go.

Maybe adopting something like https://pypi.org/project/simplemind/ (https://github.com/ErikBjare/gptme/issues/233) makes sense long-term, if simple and pliable enough.
issues.author: ErikBjare

comments.author: ErikBjare
comments.body: Experimented with a lot of the linting/checking stuff in https://github.com/ErikBjare/gptme/pull/199, without going the hook approach.

issues.title: openrouter key doesn't get used again after initial setup!
issues.body:
Cool project! I've been enjoying playing with it, but I keep running into an issue: I primarily use OpenRouter, so during the initial setup I pasted in an OpenRouter API key at this screen:

```
No API key set for OpenAI, Anthropic, or OpenRouter.
You can get one at:
 - OpenAI: https://platform.openai.com/account/api-keys
 - Anthropic: https://console.anthropic.com/settings/keys
 - OpenRouter: https://openrouter.ai/settings/keys
 
Your OpenAI or Anthropic API key: 
```

The wording in the last prompt was a little confusing since I was pasting in an OpenRouter key not an OpenAI or Anthropic key, but I was pleasantly surprised to see that once I pasted it in everything worked and it even auto-selected an appropriate model to use with OpenRouter.

However after that every time I quit and restart `gptme` I get the screen from above again and have to paste the openrouter key to before it will let me do anything, even though the key is already added to `config.toml` under `[env]`.

Here's what my `config.toml` looks like:
```toml
[prompt]
about_user = "I am a curious human programmer."
response_preference = "Basic concepts don't need to be explained."

[prompt.project]
activitywatch = "ActivityWatch is a free and open-source automated time-tracker that helps you track how you spend your time on your devices."

issues.title: Optimizing tool-use by guiding without explicit instruction
issues.body:
Optimizing tool-use messages like saves and patches by rewriting inefficient calls to more efficient versions, guiding the model towards correct tool-use without explicit instruction/self-correction.

Since a while back we emit a warning if the agent made an inefficient patch, the agent will respect the warning, but also annoying acknowledge it. I've thought of adding the reverse for save (including better save previews), but instead I got this idea of quietly replacing inefficient save/patches with efficient versions, subtly guiding the LLM to the better way.

Saving:
 - Inefficient saves could be replaced by patch

Patches:
 - Verbose patches (excessive context) could be reduced
 - Inefficient patches could be replaced by save

I'm not sure if there are other cases where we could/should do the same.

We could also use such a rewriting strategy to replace invalid save/patch formats with valid ones: https://github.com/ErikBjare/gptme/issues/153

issues.title: How should prompt-chaining work?
issues.body:
I thought that `gptme "first prompt" - "second prompt"` would wait for the first prompt to completely finish (exhaust without a command given), but turns out it runs the second prompt as soon as tools for the first one are given.

Example:

```
$ gptme 'what is 2+2' - 'what is the last answer times 23'
User: what is 2+2
Assistant: To calculate 2+2, I can use Python:

\```python
2 + 2
\```
Out[1]: System:
Executed code block.

Result:
\```
4
\```
User: what is the last answer times 23
Assistant: To calculate the last answer (4) times 23, I'll use Python again:

\```python
4 * 23
\```
```

What could be a good test case so we can test for this in CI? Something where it needs both a tool result and to comment/summarize or run more tools before it can generate an answer for the second prompt (the result of which should contain an expected flag to test for the presence of).
issues.author: ErikBjare

issues.title: Subagent tool & smarter ways to handle context
issues.body:
When working on gpt-engineer I notice one benefit which is that the context per request is a lot smaller, because we don't keep sending past conversation history. This also saves massively on OpenAI spend.

This could be achieved by giving gptme a "subagent" tool, which can run a complex tasks that require back-and-forth, and for which the required context is clearly scoped, and a clear-defined result.

Examples of such tasks include:
 - performing some data analysis where we are only interested in the answer/resulting plot
 - writing & applying a code change with a set of files as context/input (potentially with use of #59) 

This might require some change to the data model, to support the notion of subconversations, or perhaps an arbitrary metadata field that isn't send to the LLM, and can thus be used to store subconversations.

Or maybe we just store all subconversations as their own files (possibly in their own directory), and reference them in the raw conversation log.

The user should be able to interact with the subconversation (if needed, to debug or such).

```
Assistant: The traceback indicates that there is a `ValueError` being raised when the `gptme` application attempts to convert a string to an integer. The error occurs in the `run_command` method of the `shell.py` file, specifically at the line where it tries to convert the string `return_code_str` to an integer with the expression `int(return_code_str)`.

The string that is causing the error is `'?$'`, which is not a valid integer literal, hence the `ValueError`. It seems that the code is expecting a numeric return code from a shell command, but instead, it's getting a string that likely represents the last return code variable (`$?`) from the shell.

To resolve this issue, the code should be reviewed to ensure that it correctly captures the return code from the executed shell command. It's possible that the code is mistakenly capturing the string `'?$'` instead of the actual return code.

If you have access to the `shell.py` file and can modify it, you should look for the part of the code that sets `return_code_str` and ensure that it correctly captures the numeric return code from the shell command. If you need assistance with this, please let me know, and I can guide you through the process of debugging and fixing the code.                                                                                                              User:                   

i had it write a python script to read it and it came up with this

 The `shell.py` file defines a `ShellSession` class that manages a subprocess running a shell (bash in this case). It provides methods to run shell commands and capture their output and return code. Here's a summary of the key components:

- `ShellSession.__init__`: Initializes a `Popen` subprocess with `bash` and sets up pipes for `stdin`, `stdout`, and `stderr`. It also defines a delimiter to identify the end of command output.
- `ShellSession.run_command`: Takes a shell command as input, executes it, and captures the output and return code. It uses the delimiter to determine when the command output has ended.
- `ShellSession.close`: Closes the `stdin` of the subprocess and terminates it.
- `get_shell`: Returns a global instance of `ShellSession`, initializing it if it doesn't already exist.
- `set_shell`: Sets the global instance of `ShellSession`, used for testing.
- `execute_shell`: Takes a shell command as input, optionally asks for confirmation to execute, runs the command using `ShellSession.run_command`, and yields a `Message` with the command output.
- `_format_block_smart`: Formats the command output smartly, either as a single line or as a code block, depending on its length.
- `_shorten_stdout`: Shortens the command output to a specified number of lines, removing common prefixes and timestamps.

The `run_command` method is particularly important as it seems to be the source of the error you encountered. It constructs a command string that includes the original command and appends code to print the return code followed by a delimiter. After executing the command, it reads from the subprocess's `stdout` and `stderr`, looking for the delimiter and the "ReturnCode:" string to extract the return code.

The error you encountered (`ValueError: invalid literal for int() with base 10: '$?'`) suggests that the code is incorrectly capturing the string `'?$'` instead of the actual numeric return code. This could be due to a bug in how the output is parsed or how the return code is captured.

If you need to fix this issue, you would need to ensure that the `run_command` method correctly parses the return code from the command output. If you have access to modify the `shell.py` file, you could add additional logging or error handling around the return code parsing to diagnose the problem further.

issues.title: Add per-test timeouts
issues.body:
- Each fast test should run in under ~5s
   - This is just a matter of marking them as slow if so.
 - Each slow test should run in under ~30s
   - Timeout should thus be 30s per test.
 - Evals could potentially be slower, but such evals should not be run as part of normal test suite.

Right now the entire run times out in CI after 5 min, at which point a test gone wrong might be able to spend a lot of tokens.

Should use: https://pypi.org/project/pytest-timeout/

Fixed now!

However, do note that the ```patch codeblocks are not meant for the actual diff/patch format (since GPTs can't reliably generate them, failing on the line number math). Instead they use a git-conflict-marker like syntax, like this:

````
```patch hello.py
<<<<<<< ORIGINAL
    prin

issues.title: Tree-based LogManager
issues.body:
I asked ChatGPT about it, and it seems doable: https://chat.openai.com/share/5b63c61e-0b82-43ee-b305-d283deba51fb

Would enable the user to stop worrying about "losing" conversation history, and let them browse the branching nature of the convo like in the ChatGPT UI.

Some complications around:

 - editing
   - after editing the conversation, read the messages and find the common ancestor and branch from there
 - saving/loading
   - a solution could be to store each branch as a log in the conversation folder side-by-side with the "main" `conversation.jsonl` branch.
issues.author: ErikBjare
